TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in the town of Biysk in LOC .

CARDINAL . The applicant stated that the residents of her block of flats were embroiled in a conflict with a group of teenagers who frequently gathered in front of the building to drink alcohol , litter the yard and make noise until TIME .

CARDINAL . On DATE several residents , including the applicant and her partner PERSON . , tried to disperse the teenagers . A quarrel followed . CARDINAL of the teenagers swore at them . PERSON retorted that “ youngsters like these should be killed ” . The teenagers ran immediately to the nearby police station where they complained that PERSON . had threatened them with a gun and had fired a shot at them .

CARDINAL . TIME several police officers came running to the spot and required that PERSON . surrender his gun . They were drunk . PERSON denied having a gun . The applicant told him to go home and he left . The policemen did not attempt to stop him .

CARDINAL . After a while the police officers decided to arrest PERSON . and rang his doorbell . PERSON refused to open it . The neighbourhood police officer ( участковый ) Mr T. was determined to get into the apartment through the balcony and called the fire brigade , which brought an extension ladder .

CARDINAL . Mr T. and another police officer , PERSON , climbed the ladder and broke the balcony window . The applicant heard two shots . She believed that Mr T. had fired the first shot at PERSON . and then fired in the air . When she entered the flat she saw that PERSON . was dead .

CARDINAL . At TIME on DATE the neighbourhood police officer Mr T. heard a gunshot and saw several teenagers running towards him . They said that a man had just fired a shot at them and pointed at PERSON . He saw PERSON . give something to the applicant , who then entered the building . He ran after her and made her come back . At that time other police officers arrived on the scene .

CARDINAL . Mr Sh . behaved aggressively , in particular brandishing a shovel at the police officers , and Mr T. thought that he was drunk . He ordered Mr PERSON . to surrender his gun . PERSON denied having any weapon . Mr T. wanted to search him but was prevented from doing so by other residents of the block of flats . PERSON . took advantage of the situation and escaped to his flat . He locked the door and refused to let PERSON in . PERSON asked the applicant to open the door or give him the key , but she refused .

CARDINAL . Mr T. asked CARDINAL of the police officers to watch the door . He then called the police officer on duty and asked for instructions . The police officer instructed him to force the door open and arrest Mr. PERSON . As he was unable to force the door open , Mr T. decided to get into the flat through the balcony and asked the officer on duty to call the fire brigade . At that moment a patrol team arrived at the scene .

CARDINAL . Once the fire brigade had arrived , PERSON and a police patrol officer Mr PERSON climbed the extension fire ladder . PERSON attempted to prevent them from entering the balcony . He threatened to kill them and brandished a gun - like object . Mr T. ordered PERSON . to lay down his weapon , warned him that he would shoot and fired in the air . PERSON hit PERSON on the head with the heavy metal object he was holding . PERSON , who was standing behind Mr T. on the ladder , saved him from falling from the third floor . When PERSON . attempted to hit PERSON a second time , PERSON at PERSON . , fatally wounding him . The police officers carried PERSON . into the bedroom and immediately called an ambulance . The doctors certified Mr PERSON . dead and examined Mr T.

CARDINAL . ORG of LOC conducted an internal inquiry into the incident . Having inspected the scene of the incident and having questioned the police officers involved , it established the following facts :
- Mr T. and other police officers believed that PERSON . was armed as they had heard a gunshot and witnesses had stated that he had fired at them ;
- Mr Sh . had been aggressive and apparently drunk ;
- the residents of the block of flats prevented Mr T. from searching Mr Sh . and , by retaining the police officers , gave him an opportunity to escape to his flat ;
- Mr T. called the police station of LOC for instructions . The police officer on duty , Major NORP , told him to call the Biysk police station ;

- Mr T. called the Biysk police station . The police officer on duty , Major P. , ordered him to force the door open and arrest PERSON . Mr T. explained to PERSON that he would be unable to force the door open as he did not have the requisite equipment . He further stated that it would be possible to access the flat through the balcony . Major PERSON called a fire brigade ;
- After Mr T. and PERSON had climbed up an extension fire ladder , PERSON . barred their access to the balcony and brandished a gun - like object at them ;
- Mr T. ordered PERSON . to put down his weapon and fired a warning shot in the air ;
- Mr Sh . hit PERSON on the head and nearly threw him down from the third floor . After PERSON . had attempted to hit PERSON a second time , Mr T. fired at him ;
- The police officers called an ambulance . The ambulance doctors established that PERSON . was dead and that PERSON had concussion .

CARDINAL . In his report of DATE an acting head of ORG of LOC concluded that PERSON had acted in compliance with the rules governing the conduct of the police . The use of weapon had been justified by the circumstances and lawful in accordance with section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of LAW . On the other hand , he found that the casualty had occurred as a result of negligence on the part of the officers on duty , Major NORP and PERSON , who had not recorded the information received from PERSON , had not informed their superiors about the on - going incident and had not sent reinforcements to PERSON He ordered that Major NORP be demoted and Major PERSON be reprimanded . He further reprimanded the head of the police station of LOC and the head of the NORP police station for unsatisfactory training and poor discipline of their subordinate officers .
CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office of GPE of Biysk opened criminal proceedings in respect of PERSON 's resistance to the police .
CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office inspected the flat and seized a metal pestle stained with blood . No gun was found in the flat .
CARDINAL . On DATE the case was transferred to the prosecutor 's office of GPE . The prosecutor 's office inspected the flat anew and seized a cartridge case .

CARDINAL . On DATE the experts performed an autopsy on PERSON body . They noted a gunshot wound to his chest and several bruises and abrasions to his body and head . The experts described PERSON 's position at the moment of the shot and the trajectory of the bullet . They concluded that the wound had been fatal . They further stated that it was highly probable that the bruises and abrasions on PERSON face had been the result of his falling and hitting a hard object , while the bruises on his wrists , right arm , chest and right buttock had been caused as a result of his being gripped and dragged . All injuries had been inflicted shortly before the death , most likely while he was dying . The level of alcohol in PERSON . 's blood and urine showed that he had been moderately intoxicated .

CARDINAL . On DATE an expert examined Mr T. 's medical record . He noted that on DATE PERSON had been taken to hospital , where he had remained until DATE . He had been diagnosed with an injury to his head and concussion . The expert concluded that the injury could have been received on DATE . He also noted that there was no indication of alcohol intoxication in Mr T. 's medical record .
CARDINAL . On DATE experts carried out blood group tests . The tests revealed that the blood on the pestle could have been PERSON . It could not have been PERSON .
CARDINAL . On DATE a ballistic examination was performed .

CARDINAL . The prosecutor questioned Mr T. and the applicant , who gave their versions of the incident . CARDINAL of the teenagers was also questioned . She testified that PERSON . had been in possession of a gun and had fired at her and her friends .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office of LOC discontinued the criminal proceedings , those against PERSON . because he was dead , and those against Mr T. for the absence of corpus delicti in his actions .
CARDINAL . On DATE the decision was annulled by a supervising prosecutor , who transferred the case to the prosecutor 's office of Biysk and ordered an additional inquiry .

CARDINAL . In the course of the additional inquiry the prosecutor questioned police officer Mr PERSON and other police officers who had participated in the incident of CARDINAL DATE . They confirmed PERSON testimony .

CARDINAL . NORP The teenagers testified unanimously that PERSON . had threatened them with a gun and had fired at them . They also stated that PERSON . had quarrelled with the police officers and had brandished a shovel at them .

CARDINAL . The residents of the applicant 's block of flats testified that PERSON . had not had any weapon and had not fired at the teenagers . The policemen who had been called by the teenagers had been drunk and had behaved rudely . When PERSON . had expressed his intention to leave , the policemen had not tried to stop him . However , subsequently they had decided to enter his flat through the balcony and arrest him . Although all the residents had assured them that PERSON . did not present any danger and had urged them to postpone the inquiry into the incident until TIME , the police officers persisted in their attempt to arrest PERSON . immediately . In the witnesses ' opinion climbing onto the balcony had been inopportune and unnecessary . They had all heard the police officer fire CARDINAL shots . Some of them stated that the first shot had been aimed at PERSON . and the second in the air .

CARDINAL . One of the applicant 's neighbours , PERSON , stated that on DATE he had been in his flat . He had heard a gunshot and looked out of the window . He had seen a man chasing a group of teenagers . A police officer had appeared and tried to arrest them . However , several women had prevented the police officer from approaching the man who had escaped to his flat . He had then seen QUANTITY police officers climbing an extension ladder and attempting to access the balcony of the man 's flat . He had heard one of the policemen shout a warning , fire in the air and , several moments later , fire a second shot . The police officer had then accessed the balcony . PERSON was sure that the first shot had been fired in the air but he could not tell what the direction of the second shot had been . He stated firmly , however , that both shots had been fired while the police officer was still on the ladder and not yet on the balcony .

CARDINAL . The prosecutor 's office also questioned Major NORP and PERSON , who had been on duty on DATE and had given instructions to PERSON on the telephone . They denied giving any orders to PERSON They had had the impression that PERSON was strongly convinced that PERSON . was armed . They had offered to send reinforcements , but Mr T. had declined . Mr T. had asked for permission to enter the flat through the balcony , and that permission had been given to him .

CARDINAL . The prosecutor studied the ambulance records . Mr T. had been examined by the ambulance doctors who had been called to the scene on DATE . The records did not contain any indication that he had been intoxicated .

CARDINAL . Finally , the prosecutor questioned a ballistic expert who described the bullet trajectory . In particular , she stated that the bullet had gone upwards then ricocheted to the right and back . She also affirmed that a forensic simulation of the incident on the balcony would be inconclusive . It would be impossible to simulate identically the conditions in which the shooting had occurred , for the following reasons : firstly , blank bullets had a different trajectory as compared with live bullets ; secondly , it would be necessary to simulate the position of the person who had fired the shot to within QUANTITY , otherwise the bullet would ricochet differently .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office of Biysk discontinued the criminal proceedings for lack of corpus delicti in Mr T. 's actions . It found that Mr T. had used his weapon in lawful self - defence from an attack by PERSON . His actions had been in conformity with LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE the decision was annulled by a supervising prosecutor who ordered an additional inquiry .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office of Biysk discontinued the criminal proceedings for the same reasons as before . On DATE the supervising prosecutor ordered that the criminal proceedings be resumed . The case was transferred to the prosecutor 's office of LOC .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office of LOC reconsidered the previous decision to discontinue the criminal proceedings against PERSON . It found that the proceedings should have been discontinued on the ground of lack of corpus delicti in his actions rather than on the ground of his death . There was no evidence that PERSON . had been armed , let alone that he had fired at the teenagers . It followed from the witness statements that he had not offered any resistance to the police officers who had arrived at the scene and that the police officers had not attempted to stop him from leaving . After he had locked himself in his flat he could no longer disturb public order , so PERSON and the other police officers ' attempts to enter his flat through the door or the balcony and arrest him had been unlawful and unjustified . By resisting those attempts PERSON . had been defending his constitutional right to respect for the privacy of his home and his liberty . Mr PERSON . had been found in his underwear , which showed that he had been resting when PERSON had tried to access his balcony . Mr T. 's statement that PERSON . had hit him with a pestle was open to doubt as the pestle had been found in the bedroom rather than on the balcony . Moreover , the expert examination had revealed that the blood on the pestle had been PERSON . Accordingly , PERSON 's actions had not constituted any administrative or criminal offence . Mr T. had abused his office and had unlawfully and unjustifiably used his weapon against Mr Sh .
CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office of GPE resumed the investigation against Mr T.
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was granted victim status and joined the proceedings as a civil party .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr T. was formally charged with murder , abuse of office associated with the use of violence or entailing serious consequences , and breach of the inviolability of the home , offences under Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL , CARDINAL § CARDINAL and QUANTITY of LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office of LOC prepared a bill of indictment . It analysed the collected evidence and concluded that the use of lethal force against PERSON . had not been justified by the circumstances . It found that after receiving the report that PERSON . had fired a shot at the teenagers Mr T. should have verified that information by questioning eyewitnesses to the incident and inspecting the area in search of a cartridge case . He had failed to search the area , however . The eyewitnesses had affirmed that PERSON . did not have any weapon and no weapon had subsequently been found in his flat . In those circumstances , Mr T. could not have had a reasonable suspicion that Mr PERSON . had committed criminal or administrative offences . Moreover , after he had locked himself in his flat he could no longer present any danger to the public . There had therefore been no reason to arrest him . In any event , before proceeding with the arrest , PERSON should have contacted his superior to ask for detailed instructions . He had not done so . Finally , PERSON had had no legal grounds for using his weapon against PERSON . Although PERSON . had indeed showed resistance , he had acted lawfully to protect his legitimate interests , namely , the privacy of his home and his liberty . By attempting to enter PERSON 's flat through the balcony and by shooting him , PERSON had abused his office , had trespassed on PERSON 's home and had committed murder . He had committed criminal offences punishable by ORG CARDINAL § CARDINAL , CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW . The prosecutor also examined the origin of the bruises and abrasions on Mr Sh . 's face and body . Referring to the expert opinion , he concluded that some of the injuries had been the result of PERSON 's falling on the floor after being shot , while the remaining ones had been inadvertently caused when he had been carried to the bedroom by PERSON and another police officer .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr T. was committed for trial before ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG refused to admit the expert opinions of DATE in evidence , as they had been made in the context of criminal proceedings against PERSON . The court commissioned additional expert opinions . The experts conducted their examination and submitted their report in DATE confirming the conclusions drawn by the experts in DATE .
CARDINAL . During the hearing the accused and the witnesses confirmed their previous statements . The applicant was present at the hearings and made oral submissions to the court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG acquitted PERSON of all charges . The court was convinced by the teenagers ' and the police officers ' testimony and PERSON statements that Mr Sh . had indeed possessed a gun and had used it , and that he had offered resistance to the police officers who were trying to search him and stop him from escaping to his flat . Although the gun had never been found , the court surmised that Mr Sh . could have thrown it away after he had left the scene . As the prosecution had not searched the surroundings , such a possibility could not be excluded . The court gave the accused the benefit of the doubt and assumed that PERSON . had been armed . More importantly , after questioning the teenagers Mr T. had formed the conviction that PERSON . had been in possession of a weapon and had been a danger to the public . In those circumstances , his decision to arrest Mr PERSON . immediately had been reasonable and justified . As PERSON . had refused to let PERSON in , the applicant had refused to give the key to the police officers and it had been impossible to force the door open , PERSON had taken a correct and lawful decision to climb up onto the balcony . That decision had been approved by the duty officer of LOC of PERSON and the duty officer at ORG police station .

CARDINAL . The court further found that the use of lethal force had been necessary in the circumstances as PERSON . had offered resistance and put Mr T. 's life in danger . The court established that after PERSON had climbed up the extension fire ladder onto the balcony on the third floor PERSON . had barred his access to the balcony and attempted to throw him down . In accordance with the rules governing the conduct of policemen , PERSON had fired a warning shot . Given that PERSON . had attempted to push him down again , PERSON had fired at him . The court found that PERSON life had been in peril and that he had acted in reasonable self - defence and in compliance with LAW . The court finally noted that an internal inquiry by ORG of LOC had concluded that PERSON had been sober . The court refused to hear a civil claim by the applicant .
CARDINAL . The prosecutor appealed to ORG . The applicant also lodged an appeal , but ORG refused to hear it , finding that the applicant did not have victim status .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined the prosecutor 's appeal and dismissed it . It endorsed the reasoning of the trial court and upheld the acquittal .
CARDINAL . Murder is punishable by DATE imprisonment ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ) .
CARDINAL . Abuse of office associated with the use of violence or entailing serious consequences carries a punishment of DATE imprisonment ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Breach of the inviolability of the home , that is , unlawful entry into a home against the will of its occupants , associated with abuse of office , is punishable with a fine , a prohibition on occupying certain positions , or DATE imprisonment ( LAW of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Anyone who has caused damage to an attacker when acting in legitimate defence , that is , in self - defence or in defence of another person or the public interest , is exempted from criminal liability provided that he has not exceeded the bounds of legitimate defence . Anyone , irrespective of his or her professional or other special training or position , is entitled to exercise legitimate defence . A person is entitled to exercise legitimate defence even in situations where it is possible to avoid the dangerous attack or ask for help from other persons or authorities . The bounds of legitimate defence are exceeded if a person deliberately commits actions that are clearly disproportionate to the nature and degree of dangerousness of the attack ( Article DATE ) .

CARDINAL . Anyone who has caused damage to a perpetrator of a criminal offence when arresting that person for the purpose of bringing him or her before the competent authorities or preventing him or her from committing a further criminal offence is exempted from criminal liability , provided that it was impossible to arrest the offender by other means and the force used did not exceed what was necessary in the circumstances . The force used may not be considered necessary if it is clearly disproportionate to the nature and degree of dangerousness of the criminal offence committed and the circumstances in which the arrest is effected , or if the damage caused is clearly excessive and unwarranted by the circumstances . Criminal liability arises only if such damage has been deliberately caused ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . LAW ( no . CARDINAL-I of DATE with further amendments ) provides that the duties of the police are , among others , the prevention and suppression of criminal and administrative offences and the protection of public order and public safety ( section CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provides that when discharging their duties the police may , in particular :
( CARDINAL ) search citizens and their belongings if there are sufficient reasons to believe that they possess weapons , ammunition , explosives or drugs ;
( CARDINAL ) arrest persons suspected of a criminal offence or persons who have been remanded in custody by a judicial order ;

( CARDINAL ) enter property or land belonging to citizens or companies and search it in pursuit of a person suspected of a criminal offence or if there are sufficient grounds to believe that a criminal offence has been or is being committed there or an accident has happened there , or in order to protect public order and the personal security of citizens in cases of natural or anthropogenic disaster , or epidemic , epizootic or public disorder . A prosecutor must be informed within TIME of any entry into private LOC or land performed against the will of the owner ;

( CARDINAL ) cordon off , following a decision by the head or a deputy head of the relevant police station , a specific area for the purpose , inter alia , of catching a person suspected of a criminal offence ;

( CARDINAL ) temporarily limit or bar access of vehicles and pedestrians to a specific area , or require them to leave a specific area for the purpose of protecting citizens ' life , health and property or conducting a search or investigative measures ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The police may use physical force , special equipment or a weapon only in the circumstances specified in LAW and in accordance with the rules prescribed by that LAW . Police officers must undergo specific training and be periodically tested for their fitness to act in conditions requiring use of physical force , special equipment or a weapon ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) )
CARDINAL . NORP Before using physical force , special equipment or a weapon the police officer must :

- warn of his intention to use physical force , special equipment or a weapon and give the person concerned sufficient time to comply with his order , except in cases where the delay in using physical force , special equipment or a weapon creates an immediate danger for the life and health of citizens and police officers , is likely to cause other serious consequences or where the warning is impossible or impracticable in the circumstances ;

- endeavour to minimise the damage caused by the use of physical force , special equipment or a weapon , to the extent possible depending on the nature and seriousness of the offence , dangerousness of the person who has committed it and degree of resistance offered ;
- ensure that anyone who has been injured as a result of use of physical force , special equipment or a weapon receives first aid and that their relatives are informed without delay ;
- inform a prosecutor of any use of physical force , special equipment or a weapon involving injuries or death ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . Abuse of the power to use physical force , special equipment or a weapon is punishable by law ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . Police officers may use physical force , including martial arts , to stop a criminal or administrative offence being committed , arrest persons who have committed a criminal or administrative offence or overcome resistance to a lawful order , if non - violent methods are insufficient to ensure discharge of the police duties ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Special equipment ( truncheons , handcuffs , tear gas , electroshock devices , equipment for destroying barriers , etc . ) may be used , inter alia , to overcome a person 's resistance to the police , arrest a person caught in the act of committing a crime against life , health or property and attempting to escape , or a person who is reasonably suspected of intending to offer armed resistance to the police ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Police officers may use weapons , inter alia , to repel an attack on a police officer if his life and health are in danger ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) ) or to arrest a person caught in the act of committing a serious crime against life , health or property and attempting to escape or a person offering armed resistance ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) ) . The head of the relevant police station must be informed , within TIME , of any use of a weapon ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . It is prohibited to use weapons which may cause unnecessarily serious injuries or involve unjustifiably high risks ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . A police officer may pull out his weapon and prepare it for use if he believes that circumstances referred to in section CARDINAL may arise in the situation . If the arrestee attempts to come closer to the armed police officer than the latter allows or attempts to touch his weapon , the police officer may use his weapon in accordance with section CARDINAL ) ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Police officers are not liable for any physical , pecuniary or non - pecuniary damage caused to the offender as a result of the use , in accordance with this LAW , of physical force , special equipment or a weapon if that damage is proportionate to the resistance offered ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . The provisions of LAW concerning exemption from criminal liability for damage caused , in particular , in legitimate defence , when arresting a person who has committed a criminal offence or in pursuance of a lawful order are applicable to police officers ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The Instruction on duties and responsibilities of a neighbourhood police officer , adopted by ORG on DATE ( Order no . CARDINAL ) , provides that a neighbourhood police officer ( участковый ) is a representative of a town or district police office in a neighbourhood . His duties include , inter alia , the protection of the personal safety and property of citizens , the protection of public order and public safety and the prevention and suppression of criminal and administrative offences within the neighbourhood for which he is responsible ( paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

DATE . If a neighbourhood police officer receives information about a criminal or administrative offence or other events endangering personal or public safety he must immediately inform the police officer on duty at the relevant police station and take the measures required by law . In particular , he must take measures to guard the crime scene , find witnesses , administer first aid to victims , find and arrest the suspected offender , and find and seize stolen property , the instruments of the crime and other material evidence ( paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . A neighbourhood police officer may order that citizens and officials cease committing a criminal or administrative offence or any other activity hindering the police 's lawful actions ( paragraph CARDINAL ) . In cases specified by law he may arrest and search a person or his / her belongings and may also seize weapons and other objects and documents found during the search ( paragraph CARDINAL ) . A neighbourhood police officer may enter residential or other LOC and land belonging to citizens or companies and search them in pursuit of a person suspected of having committed a criminal offence or if there are sufficient grounds to believe that a criminal offence has been or is being committed there or an accident has happened there , or in order to protect public order and the personal security of citizens in cases of natural or anthropogenic disaster , or epidemic , epizootic or public disorder . A prosecutor must be informed within TIME of any entry into private LOC or land performed against the will of the owner ( paragraph CARDINAL ) . A neighbourhood police officer may arrest and bring to a police station a person suspected of having committed a criminal offence or other persons in the cases prescribed by law ( paragraph CARDINAL ) . He may carry a weapon and other special equipment and use them in the cases specified in LAW ( paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The Instruction on cooperation between interior departments and services in investigation of crimes , adopted by ORG on DATE ( Order no . CARDINAL ) , provides that if a police officer on duty at a police station receives information about a criminal offence he must send a quick reaction team and a patrol team to guard the crime scene , to cut off the offenders ' escape routes or block off their hiding places , to arrest the offenders and to take witness evidence . He must also send an investigation team supplied with the requisite communication facilities , investigative equipment and vehicles . The duty police officer must keep in contact with the police officers at the scene in order to receive up - to - date information about the situation and make decisions about additional measures , and to inform the police officers at the scene of any relevant data contained in the police databases . The duty police officer must immediately inform his superior and the officer on duty at the higher - level police station of the criminal offence and then keep them informed of the measures taken ( paragraph CARDINAL ) .
